bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, September 13, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] inquires about Lazear's college career. He discusses a possible guest list for the Lazear Building dedication ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, September 13, 1940
div1.p:
I shall answer much of your letter personally but hasten to answer
at least part here. If Pew comes across, you are at liberty to use the $200.00 in
any way you wish and I think it would be nice indeed to send part of it to Kissinger.
I should not think you would be expected to pay the expenses of either Moran's wife
or Kissinger's wife. They have enough money to do that.

Please thank Miss Hough greatly for the photographs. I am placing
them in interested hands, and while I am not asking for any money for the memorial,
it may occur to them that they may wish to take part.

I am not completely straightened out on the matter of Lazear's
course at W. and J. Did he take his Bachelor's Degree at W. and J. and also take another
one at Hopkins? I agree with you that it isn't necessary to stress his leaving W. and
J. and I will merely say that he later did work at Hopkins and Columbia. I am glad to
have Barker's letter. Most of this I knew and have already read most of his articles.

I still haven't located Mrs. Reed. I thought she was dead but that
her daughter was living. General Kean just wrote me that he had written to her and I
am asking for her address. Thank you for sending me Mrs. Lazear's address. I have
been trying to get it, without success, and did not know that you knew it.

Aside from Mrs. Lazear, and perhaps Walter Reed's son and daughter,
the five persons most concerned with the yellow fever experiments in this country are
Moran, Kissinger, General Truby of San Francisco (who was the officer in charge of
the hospital at Columbia Barracks, who was present at Lazear's death and who took from
his coat the precious note book concerning his experiments), General Kean, who was
Reed's friend, and Dr. Cooke. Whether you wish to invite Kean, Truby and Cook, I do
not know. I should assume that they are men of sufficient means to pay their own way.
Doubtless, they would at least appreciate the information. If you are honoring Moran
and Kissinger, perhaps Dr. Cooke should come in for similar honor. While Moran and
Kissinger accepted the experimental bites and developed experimental yellow fever, it was
Dr. Cooke who sat, with two other volunteers, in the foul, Infected Clothing Building
(see my memorandum). So putrid were the surroundings that on their first attempt, they
had to rush out, and one of the volunteers actually vomited. They slept surrounded by
the bloody and soiled effects of the dead, and according to the popular notion, thoroughly
expected to get yellow fever. The fact that they did not was not their fault and
destroyed the popular notion. Dr. Cooke still lives modestly at Lexington, Virginia.
I have just heard from him and he will help me in any way possible in writing the story.
These three alone never received pay for their contribution. All the rest did. I have
no doubt that Cooke would be delighted to be invited.

I hope you are writing Moran so that he can plan to be there and I
hope that Pew comes across. I hear from General Kean that Moran is to be the guest of
honor at a dinner given by the medical faculty of the University of Virginia on October 24.
I more or less instigated this when I was in Charlottesville last Spring.
